Complaint Seeks to Ban Senior Banking Discounts
DOC.TEXT: A 45-year-old businessman is seeking to outlaw the widespread practice of offering banking discounts to older customers. Peter Levine, in a complaint filed with Broward County's Human Relations Division, asks that county banks cease the deals to those 55 or older. ``I don't have anything against older people,'' said Levin, owner of a tote bag manufacturing business in Hialeah. ``I just think it's discrimination.'' ``We believe it is proper,'' said William Darby, a vice president at C&S Bank, where Levine has an account. ``A lot of restaurants, banks and movie theaters have done it for years.'' If the Human Relations Division is unable to resolve the complaint it will go to the county's Human Rights Board.
DOC.HEAD: Actor David Keith Envisions United Elders In `Grand Corp'
DOC.TEXT: Actor David Keith wants America to stop wasting a precious resource _ the wisdom of its aged. ``To harness this power of experience and challenge the energies of youth, to put the power back in the hands of experience, I proposed the Grand Corps,'' said Keith, who envisions building an organization of people 60 and older to speak out on the issues from pornography to ecology. ``When I look around the country, I see young people pushing their grandparents and the older people into a corner, putting them in front of the TV and saying, `Here, keep your mouth shut,''' Keith said. ``And I don't see the older people fighting back. I don't see them saying, `My mind is still alive. I've got good ideas that you ought to listen too.''' Keith, 35, who most recently played Oliver North in a TV miniseries and Elvis Presley on the big screen, hopes to form the first Grand Corps chapter in his hometown of Knoxville. He thinks senior citizens, once unified, could carry tremendous clout both locally and nationally because of their sheer numbers. Noting the growing percentage of elderly Americans, he said, ``Imagine 52 million letters arriving in Congress on the same day to get a pornography bill put through. They are going to listen.'' Keith said he didn't expect to get anything more from the Grand Corps than a chance to honor the love he received from his late grandparents.
DOC.HEAD: Fear of Crime Makes Elderly Prisoners in Own Homes
DOC.TEXT: Many of the retirees who move to Florida to enjoy their ``golden years'' wind up prisoners in their homes because of their fear of crime, a state task force on crime and the elderly reported. The 65-page report concluded that people over 60 are victimized less often than younger people, but ``the resulting injuries or incurred damages are more devastating'' for the older victims. ``Older persons live in abject terror of such every-day occurrences as going to the grocery store or merely stepping outside to pick up their Social Security checks,'' it said. Florida has the oldest population in the United States; by next year, more than 2.4 million people 65 and older will live in the Sunshine State. ``The high concentration of the aged in one environmental setting acts as a magnet to criminals,'' said the report by the Attorney General's Task Force on Crimes and the Elderly. ``Public housing, especially for the elderly, is a prime target for purse snatchings, robberies and burglaries.'' Additionally, the elderly are more likely to be harmed or held hostage during a burglary attempt as failing vision or hearing leave them unaware there is someone in the house. And ``the elderly are perceived by juveniles as easy targets for violence and crime,'' said the report. In addition to threats from unknown criminals, the elderly are particularly vulnerable to smooth-talkers. It is extremely easy to control someone's assets, merely by having them sign a power of attorney, and some unscrupulous funeral homes are adept at catching the elderly at vulnerable times, the report said. Among its recommendations, the task force urged creating a Department of Elderly Affairs, a measure already approved by voters in 1988. The report said the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services had become too large and bureaucratic to function efficiently and that the agency's Division of Aging and Adult Services appeared to be the poor stepchild of a cumbersome system. The report, based on research and testimony gathered during four months last winter, also noted that the state has begun revising its guardianship laws and imposing tougher penalties for crimes committed against elderly citizens.
